qas.question: What is another name for an exposure index rating?
How do some camera designs give some EI choices?

answers.text: by adjusting the sensor's signal gain in the digital realm

qas.question: Who provides the exposure index rating?
What are digital photo cameras also called?
What is an sRGB image file commonly called?

plausible_answers.text: film of the same EI rating at the same exposure

qas.question: The lightness of an sRGB file is designed to be different from what?
What is adjusted prior to conversion to analog?
What do choices do camera designs not offer?

plausible_answers.text: tradeoffs between the range of highlights that can be captured and the amount of noise introduced

qas.question: What does the choice of lightness parameters prevent?

context: For digital photo cameras ("<a3_0>digital still cameras<a3_0/>"), an <b4_0>exposure index (EI) rating<b4_0/>—commonly called <a0_0>ISO setting<a0_0/>—is specified by <a2_0>the manufacturer<a2_0/> such that the sRGB image files produced by the camera will have a lightness similar to what would be obtained with <b5_0>film of the same EI rating at the same exposure<b5_0/>. The usual design is that the camera's parameters for interpreting the sensor data values into sRGB values are fixed, and a number of different EI choices are accommodated by varying <b6_0>the sensor's signal gain<b6_0/> in the analog realm, prior to conversion to digital. Some camera designs provide at least some EI choices <a1_0>by adjusting the sensor's signal gain in the digital realm<a1_0/>. A few camera designs also provide <b7_0>EI adjustment<b7_0/> through a choice of lightness parameters for the interpretation of sensor data values into sRGB; this variation allows different <b8_0>tradeoffs between the range of highlights that can be captured and the amount of noise introduced<b8_0/> into the shadow areas of the photo.
